content: Be very vigilant when dealing with B of A... they are a "national bank" meaning to complain about them you have to go the the COC... Comptroller of the Currency in the federal government. A complaint to your Attorney General does not make it. I complained about B of A and won at the federal level...after contacting our AG here in Washington. I was discussing a mortgage loan with a Senior Bank official at our local branch... I needed the dollar figures to compare their deal to another bank I had been talking to. As you know the details and fees do vary. After handing me a packet on many of their policies and programs he said, "in that packet you will find a form to sign and put a credit number in for our Application Fee which is $550". I said we did not need to do that we would just take it out of our checking account. He said okay and I left...getting home I noticed he did not give me the "sheet" that tells you what your costs are and interest rate might be. So the next day I went back and picked up the information he left out from the Bank Manager. That night I went over the two proposals with my wife and we looked up our accounts on line...and discovered that B of A (the Senior official) took the money out of our account with a notation that it was verbally approved by the depositer and it named my wife?? We were really upset on seeing that. They took the money out of our account without a signature or okay from either of us. Needless to say I complained to the Bank, the State and the COC in the federal government. After all this a Bank official called (did not identify themselves) and said they wanted to deposit $550 in my account and needed an account number. No apologies, nothing else.

content: BofA raising salieries up to 70% Bank of America Corp. plans to increase some investment bankers’ salaries by as much as 70 percent following the takeover earlier this year of Merrill Lynch & Co., people familiar with the proposal said. “The concepts we are considering would not increase total compensation,” Brian Moynihan, Bank of America’s president of investment banking and wealth management, wrote yesterday in a memo to employees obtained by Bloomberg News. “Rather, we believe it is responsible, and consistent with the emerging public consensus, that a greater percentage of overall compensation come from fixed base salary.” Bank of America, which has received $45 billion of taxpayers’ money, may raise the annual base pay for some managing directors to about $300,000 from $180,000, said the people, who declined to be identified because the final numbers are still under discussion. Salaries for less-senior directors would climb to about $250,000 from $150,000, and vice presidents would get $200,000, up from about $125,000, the people said. Bonuses will become a “smaller” portion of total compensation, Moynihan wrote in the memo. from "bloomberg" Good thing those poor bankers got our help, in the nick of time no doubt.
